channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Air Base Is Attacked, as Ukraine Discounts Escalation Threat
item.description: Russia said falling wreckage from a Ukrainian drone had killed three servicemen at the base, some 300 miles from Ukraine, which would be the third such long-range attack this month.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A satellite image of Engels air base in Saratov, Russia, about 300 miles from the Ukrainian border. It is home to some of Russia’s nuclear-capable strategic bombers that are used to fire cruise missiles at Ukraine.

item.title: Investigating the Nord Stream Pipeline Sabotage
item.description: As investigators piece together clues, Russia has quietly taken steps to begin expensive repairs on the giant gas pipeline, complicating theories about who was behind September’s sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Justin Scheck
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A section of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany. Much of the European Union and the United States — under both President Barack Obama and President Donald J. Trump — opposed the pipeline’s construction.

item.title: China to Drop Covid Quarantine for Incoming Travelers
item.description: From Jan. 8, visitors will be required to show only a negative P.C.R. test taken within 48 hours. The restrictions had cut the country off from the rest of the world for nearly three years.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: The Beijing Daxing International Airport on Monday. In November, the number of international flights to China was 6 percent of what it was in 2019, according to the flight tracker VariFlight.

item.title: Aid Groups in Afghanistan Suspend Work After the Taliban Ban Female Staff
item.description: The government’s decree, barring women from work in local and international relief organizations, threatens critical assistance for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.media:description: Closed doors at the offices of the aid group CARE International in downtown Kabul, on Monday.

item.title: Nets, Buoys, Salt, Ice. For West African Fishermen, ‘Everything’ Is Going Up.
item.description: Fishermen in Sierra Leone need large amounts of ice to store their catch on multiday journeys. Like many commodities, it has become pricey.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Yagazie Emezi for The New York Times
item.media:description: For fishermen in Freetown, Sierra Leone, the ice they store on wooden containers on their boats has become a pricey commodity, one of too many, they say.

item.title: North Korean Drones Breach Border, Triggering Alarms in South
item.description: South Korean war planes fired warning shots, while the authorities briefly prohibited commercial planes from taking off at two international airports near Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A suspected North Korean drone at the Defense Ministry in Seoul in 2017. South Korea said on Monday that it had fired warning shots after North Korean drones violated the South’s airspace.

item.title: Nepal’s Revolving Door Produces a New Leader but No Hoped-For Change
item.description: A former rebel chief became prime minister for a third time in a country long racked by political instability.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Nepal’s newly appointed prime minister, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, during his swearing-in on Monday in Kathmandu.

item.title: With Record Military Incursions, China Warns Taiwan and the U.S.
item.description: Taiwan said China sent 71 military aircraft near the island days after President Biden bolstered U.S. support for Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien and Chang Che
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Fighter jets of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army (PLA) conducting a combat training exercise around Taiwan in August.

item.title: With ‘Zero Covid,’ China Proved It’s Good at Control. Governance Is Harder.
item.description: For a powerful government that has bragged about its command of the country, its absence at a moment of crisis has made the public question its credibility.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Testing booths, ubiquitous in China, have been mostly empty since the government abandoned its “zero Covid” policy.

item.title: Paris Shooting Suspect Indicted on Charges of Murder With Racist Motive
item.description: The suspect is accused of killing three Kurds. Prosecutors say he admitted targeting foreigners, but many Kurds see the attack as politically motivated terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A woman holding a portrait of Emine Kara, a Kurdish women’s leader who was killed last week, during a protest march on Monday in Paris.

item.title: Conservatives in Western Canada Pass Law Rejecting Federal Sovereignty
item.description: A new law in the province of Alberta radically circumscribes federal authority, advancing the agenda of the province’s far-right secessionist movement.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Near Coutts, Alberta, in August. The province has long held grievances toward the federal government.

item.title: How Citizen Spies Foiled Putin’s Grand Plan for One Ukrainian City
item.description: A partisan cell in Kherson spied on, undermined and even hunted down Russian soldiers. Now that Vladimir V. Putin’s forces are gone, people feel free to talk — and to brag a little.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oksana and Dmytro Yevminov aboard their yacht in Kherson, southern Ukraine, last month. They hid guns and sacks of grenades for resistance fighters during the Russian occupation of the city.

item.title: Putin Wants Fealty, and He’s Found It in Africa
item.description: As Moscow wages war in Ukraine, its mercenaries have already established control in the Central African Republic — with scant Western reaction.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Russian soldiers protecting civilians in central Bangui.

item.title: They Traveled From South Korea. They Got Stranded Near Buffalo.
item.description: A South Korean tour group’s van became stuck in the snow outside a house in Williamsville, N.Y. They spent the weekend with the residents — who luckily had a well-stocked kitchen.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung

item.title: The Webb Telescope Is Just Getting Started
item.description: The first scientific results are coming in, and the $10 billion instrument is working even better than astronomers had dared to hope.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Epidemics That Weren’t: How Countries Shut Down Recent Outbreaks
item.description: Some of the most fragile health systems in the world can teach us ways to respond to public health threats early and effectively.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Volunteers received training on how to conduct safe and dignified burials for Ebola victims Mubende, Uganda, in October.

item.title: Ryazan, Home of Elite Russian Unit, Still Supports Ukraine War
item.description: Ryazan, not far from Moscow, regularly sends young men off to fight. Some are now buried in the local cemetery, but there is no surge of outrage against Russian leaders.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:description: Natalia cleaning the grave of her son at a cemetery in Ryazan, Russia, in December. He was killed near Kyiv in the first days of the Ukraine war.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukrainian attacks on Russian soil.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A satellite image of Engels air base in Saratov, Russia, about 300 miles from the Ukrainian border. It is home to some of Russia’s nuclear-capable strategic bombers that are used to fire cruise missiles at Ukraine.

item.title: Soccer Star Says His Family Stopped From Leaving Iran for Supporting Protests
item.description: Ali Daei, a prominent former soccer player, said his wife and daughter were prevented from leaving Iran on Monday after their plane made an unannounced stopover en route to Dubai.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Ali Daei at the draw for the 2022 World Cup in Qatar in Doha, in April. He said his wife and daughter were prevented from leaving Iran on Monday.

item.title: How citizen spies foiled Putin’s grand plan for one Ukrainian city.
item.description: A partisan cell in Kherson spied on, undermined and even hunted down Russian soldiers. Now that Vladimir V. Putin’s forces are gone, people feel free to talk — and to brag a little.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valentyn Dmytrovych Yermolenko, a 64-year-old fisherman, led a resistance cell in a riverside community in Kherson.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Menaces Taiwan
item.description: Also, an emerging picture of China’s Covid crisis.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Fighter jets of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army (PLA) conducting a combat training exercise around Taiwan in August.

item.title: Bakhmut’s final food stand finds a way to keep the pizza coming.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:description: Andriy Shved, 41, at his street food shop in central Bakhmut last month. “In the morning, the shelling is from 8 until 9. Then, in the afternoon, it’s from 2 until 4,” he said.

item.title: This Year’s Most Read: Stories You Shared and Spent the Most Time With
item.description: Today we’re looking back on the stories you read, shared and spent the most time with.
item.dc:creator: the staff of The Morning
item.media:description: Wordle is a love story.

item.title: Ukraine is offering Russian soldiers detailed instructions on how to surrender to its drones.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier operates a drone near the Kherson front in Ukraine on September 5, 2022.

item.title: In Ukraine, Christmas lights defy the darkness of war.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Kyiv, Ukraine, a woman pedaled a bicycle generator to power the lights on a Christmas tree displayed at the railway station.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A special edition looking back at 2022.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Locking the barrier to a residential area in Shanghai under lockdown in May.

item.title: British Columbia Bus Crash Leaves 4 Dead and Dozens Injured
item.description: The authorities said an investigation was continuing but that “it is believed that extremely icy road conditions” caused the bus to roll over.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A special edition looking back at 2022.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Locking the barrier to a residential area in Shanghai under lockdown in May.

item.title: Charles Charts a Path as a King for All Holiday Seasons
item.description: Adding a Hanukkah party and Diwali treats to the traditional Christmas address, King Charles III is publicly embracing a more inclusive monarchy in his first months.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III, front right, with other members of the royal family on Sunday before the Christmas Day service at Sandringham Church in Sandringham, England.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Christmas Address Bemoans ‘Grave Famine of Peace’
item.description: Pope Francis urged the tens of thousands of faithful in St. Peter’s Square to pray for Ukraine and for others suffering in conflicts around the world.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivered his traditional Christmas Day message from the main balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican.

item.title: Covid Is Spreading Rapidly in China, New Signs Suggest
item.description: Even as official figures from the central government remain low, regional numbers point to explosive outbreaks and overstretched health care systems.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty shelves at a pharmacy in Beijing on Tuesday. There are reported shortages of fever-reducing medications.

item.title: Times Past
item.description: We’re diving into The Times’s archives with the help of a professional.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: A 1913 index for The New York Times.

item.title: U.N. Fears 180 Rohingya Refugees in Stranded Boat Are Dead
item.description: Families lost contact weeks ago with their relatives on the boat, the U.N. refugee agency says, while at least some of those on another boat adrift for weeks appear to have been rescued.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: A Rohingya man awaiting medical treatment after arriving in Aceh Province, Indonesia, on Sunday. Worries remain for another boatload of Rohingya refugees.

item.title: Another Day, Another Crash: Life by Britain’s Most Bashed Bridge
item.description: A railway bridge with a shallow underpass is bashed into by vehicles with startling regularity, causing mostly embarrassment, but sending cargo — flowers, bicycles, eggs and potatoes — flying onto the roadway.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A crash at the Stonea Bridge in 2019 closed the bridge for several weeks. No serious injuries were reported. Among the vehicles that have hit the bridge are delivery vans, a horse trailer and campers.

item.title: Putin Says He Is Open to Talks as Air-Raid Sirens Sound in Ukraine
item.description: Ukrainians appeared intent on celebrating Christmas, even if scarce power left some cities darkened, save for generator-powered holiday light displays.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families at a movie screening in a parking garage on Saturday in Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Christmas in Ukraine: Flickering Lights, Patriotic Trees and Hope for Peace
item.description: One town is protecting a statue of St. Nick with sandbags, another is putting its Christmas tree underground and others are cranking up noisy generators to keep the holiday spirit alive.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Kyiv, Ukraine, a woman pedaled a bicycle generator to power the lights on a Christmas tree displayed at the railway station.

item.title: Day 25: That Time an Orthodox Jew Celebrated Christmas
item.description: Alex Edelman, a comedian, recalls his family’s one-night fling with Christmas — undertaken as a mitzvah for a non-Jewish friend.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: Taliban Bar Women From NGOs, Threatening to Worsen Crisis
item.description: A letter from Afghanistan’s Ministry of Economy warned that it would revoke the operating licenses of any organizations that defied the decree.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Safiullah Padshah and Najim Rahim
item.media:description: A rally on Thursday in Kabul, Afghanistan, to protest the Taliban rule barring women from attending universities.

item.title: Fuel Tanker Wedged Beneath Overpass Explodes Near Hospital in South Africa
item.description: At least 10 people were killed and 60 injured from the ensuing fireball, in a scene a witness described as a “zombie apocalypse.”
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A burned out vehicle marks the spot where a gas tanker exploded under a bridge in Boksburg, east of Johannesburg on Saturday.

item.title: Indigenous Communities in Canada Still Await Safe Drinking Water
item.description: A legal victory last December raised hopes for an accelerated path to clean drinking water on Canadian reserves. But for many, the wait drags on.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Amber Bracken
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Oji-Cree people of North Spirit Lake, Ontario, once drank directly from the pristine water systems on their traditional lands. The community has been under a boil water advisory since 2001.

item.title: Storm Batters Canada, Leaving Thousands Without Power
item.description: Even Canadians accustomed to the vagaries of Arctic weather systems contended with a long list of extremes, including cold that “freezes flesh in minutes.”
item.dc:creator: Russell Goldman and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Arlyn Mcadorey/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Toronto on Friday. The weather across Canada is part of the same system affecting much of the United States.

item.title: Your Favorite Things of 2022
item.description: This week, your best highly specific best-ofs of the year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Syrian Family That Rebuilt a Chocolate Empire in Nova Scotia
item.description: Seven years on, Peace by Chocolate continues to expand, and its founder has become an advocate of more open immigration.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Tareq Hadhad, a medical student in Syria, became known in Canada for restarting a family chocolate business.

item.title: At Least 10 Killed in Kherson Shelling, Fueling Anger Over Christmas Strikes
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine had urged vigilance after the military noted the presence of Russian ships carrying cruise missiles in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: A man injured in the attack on Saturday. The streets of Kherson were busy on Saturday morning when Russian forces shelled the city center, according to an aide to the Ukrainian president.

item.title: China’s Hottest New TV Genre: Dating Shows for Older People
item.description: Several popular television programs in the country are helping to encourage conversations about the social, romantic and sexual needs of older Chinese people.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong

item.title: A Christmas Tree Brings Life to a Destroyed Palestinian Village
item.description: For former residents of Iqrit, where Israeli forces leveled everything but the church in 1951, religious rituals bind them to a place from which they were expelled.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Families gathering for the tree lighting in the Palestinian Christian village of Iqrit, Israel, this month.

item.title: What Are JDAMs? And What Will They Do For Ukraine?
item.description: The United States is giving satellite-guided bombs to Kyiv for the first time as part of a new $1.85 billion military aid package.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: South Korean Defense Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A South Korean fighter jet dropping two Joint Direct Attack Munitions in October.

item.title: Threat of Invasion From Belarus Low, Says Ukraine Spy Chief
item.description: In a wide-ranging interview on the state of the war, Kyrylo Budanov also spoke about Russia-Iran relations and Moscow’s obsession with taking the city of Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian mechanized infantry brigade near the front lines in the Donbas region on Thursday.

item.title: Russian Forces Shell Ukraine’s Kherson Region
item.description: At least five civilians were killed and 18 injured in Russian attacks on Thursday and into Friday morning, an official said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian attacks continued in Ukraine, with at least five civilians killed on Thursday and early Friday.

item.title: What Is a ‘Bomb Cyclone’?
item.description: These storms aren’t tremendously rare, but this particular one is much more powerful than most.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Joseph Cress/Iowa City Press-Citizen, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Icy conditions in North Liberty, Iowa, on Thursday.

item.title: As Hope Fades for Missing Thai Sailors, Ship’s Safety Is Scrutinized
item.description: Five days after the warship sank, 23 men remain missing. The authorities said the warship did not have enough life jackets.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A rescued sailor from the HTMS Sukhothai being transferred to land at Bang Saphan Port in Prachuap Khiri Khan Province, Thailand, on Monday.

item.title: Paris Shooting: At Least 3 Killed in Suspected Racist Attack
item.description: The shooting, which prompted protests, took place at a Kurdish community center, and a 69-year-old has been taken into custody. The authorities said he “clearly wanted to target foreigners.”
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Members of Kurdish community clashed with police officers in the area where the shooting took place.

item.title: A Brutal Storm
item.description: Just before Christmas, a combination of ice, snow and winds is paralyzing much of the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snow and wind in Chicago yesterday.

item.title: Tracking North Korea’s Record Number of Missile Launches
item.description: Kim Jong-un’s regime has launched more than 90 ballistic and other missiles in 2022 — more than in any previous year — in defiance of United Nations resolutions.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Television screens in Seoul showing a news report in November airing file footage on a North Korean missile launch.

item.title: Iran condemns Zelensky’s remarks to Congress as ‘baseless.’
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: An Iranian-made Shahed-136 drone over Kyiv in October during a Russian attack.

item.title: As Cases Explode, China’s Low Covid Death Toll Convinces No One
item.description: China’s murky statistics are fueling widespread public distrust. Its narrow definition of Covid deaths “will very much underestimate the true death toll,” the W.H.O. says.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Amy Chang Chien and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Workers moving a body to a container for storage at a crematory in Beijing. Reports of people dying after contracting Covid have soared in the two weeks since China abruptly abandoned Covid restrictions.

item.title: At German Christmas Markets, Smiles Shine Bright but Budgets Are Tight
item.description: In Nuremberg, the stalls are open without Covid restrictions, and big crowds are returning to sip mulled wine and socialize. But amid economic uncertainty, visitors are spending less.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Few places in Germany feel as Christmassy at this time of year as the Nuremberg Christkindlesmarkt, one of the oldest and most storied festive markets in the country.

item.title: His Job Description? Protecting German Democracy. Literally.
item.description: Thomas Haldenwang runs Germany’s Office for the Protection of the Constitution. His mission is to fight the enemies of German democracy — from far-right coup plotters to Russian hackers.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Haldenwang, Germany’s domestic intelligence chief, at Hambach Castle in Neustadt, Germany.

item.title: How to Travel the World While Putting Nature First
item.description: In the wake of the U.N. biodiversity conference, Julia Simpson, the head of the World Travel and Tourism Council, discusses a new initiative called nature positive travel.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: “We used to talk about leaving a lighter footprint,” said Julia Simpson (above), the president and chief executive of the World Travel and Tourism Council. “But now I think people actually want to have a positive footprint.”

item.title: The Senate passes a spending bill that includes nearly $50 billion in aid for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: The 4,155-page bill funds the U.S. government through September and substantially increases spending.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky’s return to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky is greeted in the House chambers after he addressed a joint session of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Day 23: On Christmas Day, No Rest for the Weary. (Or the Guy Who Feeds the Penguins.)
item.description: For a biologist in San Francisco, Dec. 25 will bring not presents and mistletoe, but beak trims and fish guts.
item.dc:creator: Chris Colin
item.media:credit: LeeAndra Cianci, Photo by Nicholas Albrecht for The New York Times
item.media:description: San Francisco biologist Sparks Perkins works on Christmas to tend to the needs of the resident penguins at the California Academy of Sciences’s Steinhart Aquarium. He holds an African penguin chick. New swimming feathers, stiffer and sleek, are replacing the chick’s fuzzy baby down.

item.title: Congress Votes to Expand U.S. Power to Prosecute International War Crimes
item.description: Passed after an address by Ukraine’s leader, the bill would allow foreigners in the United States who are suspected of war crimes to be tried even if the crime was overseas and the victim was not American.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Perpetrators committing unspeakable war crimes, such as those unfolding before our very eyes in Ukraine, must be held to account,” said Senator Richard J. Durbin, left, who helped shepherd the bill.
